bestBHT.bht: Be perfect in your mercy and compassion, just as the Father is perfect. Strive to be tenderhearted, kind, and generous towards all, whether they are your friends or your enemies. The goal is to emulate the mercy and compassion of God, who is often referred to as the Merciful in Jewish literature. Remember that while we seek to reflect God's perfect mercy, we are not claiming that we have already attained it.

Henry Alford: 36.] merciful—equivalent to “perfect,” Matt. v. 48, which last is the larger description, comprehending in it charity and mercy; see note there.
Archibald T. Robertson: In both the perfection of the Father is placed as the goal before his children.
In neither case is it said that they have reached it.
John Gill: Be ye therefore merciful,.... Tenderhearted, kind, beneficent to all men, friends and foes:
as your Father also is merciful."
nothing is more common in Zohar...than to express the Divine Being by no other name, than 'the Merciful'
O my people, the children of 'Israel, as your father',
רחמן, 'is merciful' in heaven, so be ye merciful on earth.

bhtAttempts.bht: Be perfect in your mercy and compassion, just as the Father is perfect. Strive to be tenderhearted, kind, and generous towards all, whether they are your friends or your enemies. The goal is to emulate the mercy and compassion of God, who is often referred to as the Merciful in Jewish literature. Remember that while we seek to reflect God's perfect mercy, we are not claiming that we have already attained it.

Be perfect in mercy, for in being merciful, we strive towards perfection, just as our Father in heaven is perfect. We are called to be tenderhearted, kind, and benevolent towards all, mirroring the merciful nature of God. This is not to say that we have already achieved this perfection, but it serves as our guiding principle. In fact, the divine name often used in the Zohar to depict God is the Merciful. Thus, as children of God, we are urged to imitate our heavenly Father's merciful character in our earthly interactions.

Strive for perfection by embodying mercy, mirroring the nature of our heavenly Father. We are called to be tenderhearted, kind, and benevolent to all, as nothing is more common than expressing God as the Merciful. Although we may not have fully attained this perfection, it remains our goal. Let us, as children of God, reflect the mercy of our heavenly Father in all our interactions on earth.

Be ye therefore merciful, tenderhearted, kind, and beneficent to all men, just as your Father in heaven is merciful. In both the perfection of the Father and the disciples' command to be merciful, the goal is set before them. Although it is not explicitly stated that they have already achieved this perfection, they are called to embody the mercy of the Father in their actions towards others. Truly, nothing is more common in the Zohar than to refer to the Divine Being as the Merciful, emphasizing the importance of showing mercy and compassion to others as an expression of our relationship with God.

Be ye therefore merciful, showing tenderheartedness, kindness, and benevolence to all people, just as your Father in heaven is merciful. Both the perfection of the Father and the disciples' command to be merciful are presented as a goal to strive for. It is not explicitly stated that they have already attained this perfection, but they are called to embody the mercy of the Father in their interactions with others. The Zohar frequently refers to the Divine Being as the Merciful, underscoring the significance of demonstrating mercy and compassion towards others in our earthly lives.
